section.title: Developing modules in lua
section.para: Reconnoiter modules can be written in Lua. Modules implementing check types as well as more generic non-check related modules can be authored in lua.

Due to Reconnoiter's event handling system, one must be careful when taking blocking actions in their lua modules as doing so can cause general malfunctions including watchdog timeouts where the process will be terminated and restarted.
Several lua bindings are available under the noit namespace are available to assist in leveraging the event system and supprting libraries.

section.title: Installing lua modules
section.para: Site to site locations may vary, but the search path for lua is specific in the noit.conf file where the lua loader is loaded. Lua files should be installed relative to this path where modules namespaces are in their own directory heirarchy. For example, noit.module.example should be in a file noit/module/example.lua relative to the search path. In a typical Reconnoiter install, if the install prefix is /opt/noit/prod, then this file would be /opt/noit/prod/libexec/noit/noit/module/example.lua.
Lua files are simply copied to this location and are available to be included via the noit configuration system.

section.title: Basic lua checks
section.para: As with any check module in Reconnoiter, there are four basic elements: documentation, initialization, configuration and performing a check. In lua modules, the documentation is actually coded and injected during the loading of the module.
Every module should start with a module declaration and documentation chunk wrapped in the onload function.

The module should then specify an initialization command and a configuration command. The options passed to the configuration function are the config parameters specified relative to the module in the configuration file, not a specific check's configuration.
Lastly, the module should provide an initiate functino that performs the check.
section.programlisting: function initiate(module, check) local now_seconds = noit.gettimeofday() check.metric_int32("seconds_since_epoch", now_seconds) check.metric_double("random", math.random()) check.available() check.good() check.status("had a good day") end
